At the same time, new predators such as seals appeared in the Southern Hemisphere. These predators didn’t just hunt the penguins, but also competed for food and space. Combined with a shrinking habitat and colder waters, these environmental pressures caused Kumimanu fordycei populations to decline, eventually leading to their extinction. However, while the giants disappeared, smaller penguins found ways to survive. 

Now, you might be wondering why the smaller penguins survived. Weren’t they facing the same problems? Well, their size actually helped them. Smaller penguins needed less food and less space, so they didn’t compete as much with seals and other predators. Their tiny bodies also made it easier for them to hide. Many small penguins could slip into burrows or tight spaces where larger predators couldn’t reach them. A great example is the little penguin, which still lives in New Zealand today. Its small size helped it survive while the giant penguins disappeared. 

What started as a funny moment at the zoo turned into a glimpse of how strange Earth’s past really was. Giant penguins like Kumimanu fordycei once thrived, but as oceans changed and new competitors appeared, adaptability mattered more than size. You can still see that same pattern today in animals all around you, as species survive by adjusting to a changing world rather than overpowering it. The story of these giant penguins reminds you that nature is always evolving, even when the changes are easy to miss. Scientists are still studying their fossils to figure out how quickly Kumimanu grew to such enormous size, how it moved in the water, what its full diet looked like, and why its population declined so dramatically, questions that show there’s still a lot we don’t fully understand about these incredible birds.

title: Three Weeks of Work
excerpt: Having productive habits is easier said than done. But throughout attempts to get good habits, personal experience leads to one question: does it really only take 21 days to build habits?
author: Sophia Huang
content:
“Do it for 21 days, and it’ll become a habit.” 

When I start doom-scrolling, my algorithm loves to taunt me with self-improvement videos titled “How to Stop RUINING Your Life with these Fifteen Helping Habits.” Then, when I also decide to start scrolling through the comments instead of actually listening to the video, I see at least forty commenters declaring, “Do it for 21 days, and it’ll become a habit.” 

I fell for that propaganda! I got myself off of my couch and actually attempted to improve myself! So when those 21 days were up, why did I not feel any more inclined to continue what I was doing? Why was it not part of my routine to sit down, meditate, and journal out my goals? 

To answer my question, I had to search the internet, demanding to know why. What I saw was the general consensus: habits usually take at least two to five months to develop. 

Of course, that left me with more questions, like the following: why did we decide to use the 21-day myth as a rule? 

It’s the same reason why I actually tried to take action to improve myself. 21 days is a rather small amount of time, even less than a month. It seems like it would be easy to keep on doing something for 21 days. The end goal is in clear sight; all you need to do is commit for 21 days before you no longer have to think about doing it. 

The 21-day rule does motivate some people to actually start on their goals, but it also un-motivates them after the 21 days are up. When nothing happens after 21 days, people may become discouraged to actually continue building their habits and stop altogether. 

For example, people never fulfill New Years’ Resolutions, which are usually an overly ambitious goal that you make, vowing to change your whole lifestyle and identity. When people see no change beyond the three week mark, they decide that their goals are too much for them. Exercise requires too much mental energy to remember to do, meditating takes too much time to get settled, and everything else does not come naturally, even after spending three long weeks trying. 

It’s not as simple as that. Some things require more time than just three weeks to become full habits, especially considering how complex they can be. If the action feels unrewarding and unhelpful, it’s only right to decide that you don’t need to continue doing it. If you cannot do it often, because something or someone physically stops you, then no habit will form. Some people may not be able to form a habit of exercising, either from the fact that they will gain little enjoyment from it or that they may be physically unable to move their body in such a way. 

However, some things can be done in even less than three weeks. So many factors impact the time frame, but most of them are rooted in the good that comes from doing the action. When you are happy when doing something, you are more likely to continue doing it. If your family and friends encourage you to act in a certain way, then you’ll follow their judgement. If you are faced with the same action every time you are in a certain location, that location will connect to the action and allow you to repeat. If you already have a routine, you can slip the action into part of it without needing to rearrange your whole life. People may be easily convinced to floss more, because they already have a routine of brushing their teeth in a certain location that allows stronger connections with the flossing action. 

Therefore, there is an uncertain amount of time needed to actually form a habit. While habit formation is definitely not around the three week mark like the 21-day rule states, it is no rigid time frame. Some take as little as a week, some as much as dozens of months. 

The 21-day myth may have been a lie, and forming good habits is a lot more difficult than just putting in the work for three weeks. Still, it’s hardly like this has changed my goals or anything, just made them a lot farther to reach.

title: Nature vs Nurture: Are Criminals Born Or Made?
excerpt: From a simple story to one of the biggest debates of our time – can the criminals we shun, actually help their behavior, or is it just programming?
author: Riya Pawar
content:
A few years ago, I heard a researcher talk about two kids at a school he was working at. One would steal lunch money. Not because he needed it, but because he enjoyed the thrill. 15 years later, the kid grew up to be an accountant with a stable job and income. Another student who was quiet and polite back then, ended up in court years later due to a number of burglaries. These two went to the same school, had the same teachers, and  a relatively similar upbringing, and yet, two completely different outcomes. 

This, and many other situations, raise the question: how much of who we are is influenced by the  situations we find ourselves in and how much is already built into us through genetics? 

The Stanford Prison Experiment, conducted by Philip Zimbardo in 1971, is one of the most well-known and influential psychology experiments to this day. A group of college students were offered a summer job where they were assigned as either a prisoner or guard and locked in the basement of Stanford University. Both groups conformed to their expected roles and let the environment influence their behavior. The guards began acting violent and harsh, while the prisoners became helpless and stressed. One prisoner even went as far as to refuse leaving because he wanted to “be a good prisoner”. Deindividualisation kicked in as people lost their sense of personal identity, and conformity pushed them to go along with what others in their group were doing. Some guards even felt cognitive dissonance but still acted according to their roles. The experiment supports the nurture side because it demonstrates how much behavior can be shaped by environment and social pressures.​​ The students’ actions weren’t predetermined, rather they responded to roles, group expectations, and the authority figures. This shows that circumstances and experiences can strongly influence how people act, making nurture a plausible explanation for behavior. 

The Asch Conformity Experiment also shows how strongly social pressure can shape behavior. In the study, participants were asked to identify which line most closely resembled the reference line in a group setting. There would be 4 actors and 1 real test subject. The actors were told to answer incorrectly, even if the correct answer is obvious. The task was so simple that even a 5 year old could do it, but when the rest of the room chose the wrong answer, so did the majority of the participants. On the other hand, when test subjects were asked to write their answers, they were less likely to conform to the group. This shows how easily social pressure can change our actions. 

Together, these studies show how quietly our environments can steer our behavior. But that’s only half the story. 

Thomas Bouchard wanted to study the impact of genetics on personality, and the Minnesota Twin Experiments was his way of doing so. By examining identical twins who had been raised in completely different environments, he found something surprising. Even though the participants had gone to different schools, had different friend groups, and their lifestyles were nothing alike, they shared many of the same core traits. One specific case was especially surprising. The “Jim Twins” were separated at birth, but later reunited at the age of 39. According to Lina Winerman at the American Psychological Association, the twins were “ both named Jim, had first wives named Linda and second wives named Betty. Both chain-smoked, drove Chevys, served as sheriff's deputies and vacationed on the same beach in Florida.” These coincidences supported Bouchard’s hypothesis that genetics play a substantial role in shaping personality, behavior, and even certain life preferences. The goal of the experiment was to show that genetic traits can remain consistent even when people are raised in very different settings. 

When we look at these studies side by side, it’s clear that human behavior isn’t just shaped by one force. Both the Stanford Prison experiment and Asch Conformity experiment show how powerful social pressure can be and how people change themselves to fit in with norms. The Minnesota Twin experiments also show how genetics and biology can influence us as well. 

So which one is it? Nature or nurture? Our innate tendencies or our environment? 

It’s actually both. The human brain is extremely complex and even has a reputation as being the most complex object in the universe due to its billions of neurons and connections. Our genetics provide a blueprint for our impulses and natural inclinations. Additionally, our experiences shape how those tendencies actually show up. 

Understanding the balance between nature and nurture can be crucial in courts. Lawyers and forensic psychologists constantly sort out whether a person’s actions can be justified. For example, a biological leaning toward being impulsive can soften consequences, but it doesn’t replace responsibility. At the same time, growing up around violence or instability can give context to why someone makes certain choices, even if it doesn’t excuse them. Modern criminology typically looks at both sides of a case before deciding on a fair outcome. Courts make decisions based on a clearer picture of what pushed or guided them toward that outcome. 

At the end of the day, we know that a combination of different factors shape us into who we are. Recognizing this blend doesn’t only help lawyers, but it can also help us understand why people do what they do. 

With that being said, genes don’t automatically mean destiny and situations aren’t everything. We can create environments that bring out the best parts of who we already are. Proving that who we want to become is not just written in our DNA, but also in the life we choose to live.

title: Pittsburgh: A City of Hills, Bridges, and Steel
excerpt: Understand how the scenic and beautiful natural landscape and surrounding geography shape Pittsburgh's identity as the “Steel City.”
author: Mikul Jain
content:
As soon as one exits the Fort Pitt tunnel from the South Side neighborhood of Pittsburgh, a breathtaking, beautiful, and majestic view of downtown opens up to the eye. In the west lies the mighty Ohio River, once considered “Great River” by the Native Iroquois tribes. Its waters make their twists and turns as far as one can see. In the east lies a scenic, perhaps even picturesque view of the gentle, rolling hills of the Appalachian Valley. These hills cast a towering view of the lively, bustling city down below where industrial and commercial neighborhoods like the Strip District and Squirrel Hill lie. On a clear summer day, one can even spot the infamous Cathedral of Learning, the tallest university campus in the western hemisphere. The hill adjacent to the tunnel displays one of the greatest transportation innovations by man: the incline. These red cabin cars make their way up and down the hill and add to the authenticity of the surrounding landscape. Finally, to the north lie the tall skyscrapers of downtown including the famous US Steel Tower (UPMC Tower) with its black facade, as well as PPG Place, also known as the “Batman building.” Now that the beautiful picture is painted, it is time to dive into the science behind Pittsburgh’s geography, its man-made wonders, as well as its historic hub as a steel manufacturing powerhouse. 

Firstly, the geography of the greater Pittsburgh area is what is known as a “plateau.” By definition, a plateau “is a flat, elevated landform that rises sharply above area on at least one side” (National Geographic, 2023). This can be acknowledged when considering the fact that western Pennsylvania is often noted as more hillier, and higher in elevation than the nearby plains and flatter lands to the west in Ohio. How did this plateau develop in the first place? Nearly 300 million years ago, Pittsburgh lay in a tropical, swampy, and humid area near the equator. Why this is important to understand is that much of Pittsburgh’s largest industries like for example coal, are the result of coal deposits that come from fossilization of ancient flora and fauna from tropical areas . Coal, as defined as “a hard, black substance that is dug from the earth in pieces” (Cambridge Dictionary, 2025). Coal therefore consists of many molecules that chemists call “hydrocarbons.” A hydrocarbon is a molecule that consists of two basic, key elements, carbon and hydrogen. These two elements are the basis of all life on our planet and what channel much of the energy in our bodies, our ecosystem, as well entire machines and vehicles. When hydrocarbons are burned or heated, they release a great amount of energy that can be used to power things like trains, engines, and even nuclear reactors. Much of Pittsburgh’s steel mills that stand today operate on from the natural coal deposits that are found underground in western Pennsylvania. Fast forward into the last 700,00 years or so, and Pittsburgh lied in a glacial area. Glaciers are defined as “a mass of ice so large that it flows under its own weight” (National Park Service, 2025). Around 20,000 years ago during the endings of the last ice age, these glaciers started to collide into each other and eventually melt. Their paths and intersections in which they collided and melted resulted in the three Pittsburgh rivers that are widely known today as the Allegheny, Ohio, and Monongahela. Today, this intersection lies at Point State Park where the three rivers meet. These rivers have played a crucial role in Pittsburgh’s development over the last few decades. Since the time of the Native Americans thousands of years ago, these rivers were used as a way of transportation for navigation much of the interior of the United States. In recent years, many shipping companies have used them to transport important goods like steel and even coal. Steel is by far the most valuable material that Pittsburgh produces today and even for much of its history. How exactly is steel produced? The science behind steel production lies in heating of coal. Sound familiar? Well, this is exactly what interlinks Pittsburgh’s greatest natural resource to its greatest man-made resource. First, coal is heated in special ovens at temperatures of over 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit! After the coal is heated and melted, it is mixed with limestone and iron ore deposits (they also are found naturally in the nearby Appalachian mountains). The molten, iron rich mixture is then refined in a way that causes it to get reduced in its carbon form. This carbon form is what is called steel. This strong, flexible, and flame resistant material is the basis of many of Pittsburgh’s greatest wonders. For example, many of the gold suspension bridges in downtown are all made from Pittsburgh-produced steel. Nearly every one of Pittsburgh’s 446 different bridges has a level of steel composition that makes them durable and sturdy enough to withstand all kinds of weather. Everything from the famous inclines, the bridges, to even the US Steel Tower itself is made with steel foundations! Now that really goes to show why Pittsburgh is given the “Steel City” title. 

The connection between geography and the science of natural resources and steel manufacturing aren’t just random and coincidental, but rather an interlinked and intertwined understanding of Pittsburgh’s establishment and renownedness as the “Steel City.”  The vast hills that resulted from the collision of tectonic plates millions of years ago, to the formation of three unique rivers from glacial activity and the existence of ancient and tropical flora underground shape Pittsburgh’s reality as one of the industrial and manufacturing powerhouse of the United States today. Understanding the science helps understand the history and future of a city built and shaped by its beautiful, scenic, and picturesque environment.

title: Photosynthesis: Explained
excerpt: Not many people know what photosynthesis really is. Dive into the world of plants and how sunlight to you is food to them!
author: Tanav Gunti
content:
When I was a wee little freshman in biology, there was one unit that I just couldn’t get my head around. Photosynthesis. The processes are complex, the reactions are complex, and honestly, even the names are complex! I mean, how is anybody supposed to memorize the path electrons take in the electron transport chain to get to the ATP synthase?  If you didn’t understand a single thing I said, then don’t worry, I am going to explain the process of photosynthesis in an easy, understandable format so you can ace your test! 

Part 0: Introduction 

Photosynthesis is the process by which plants make glucose from carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight. Basically, it's the way plants make their food. The process takes place in the chloroplast of the plant, usually located in the leaves. The greenness of the leaves that you see is actually the light that is reflected at you. Chloroplasts usually absorb blue-red-purple rays of light and reflect green rays. 

There are two main parts of photosynthesis: Light-dependent reactions and light-independent reactions.  Light-dependent reactions take place in the thylakoid membrane, while the light-independent reactions take place within the stroma of the chloroplast. Both of these parts are split into multiple smaller reactions that I will explain further. 

The main reactants (molecules used in the reaction) of photosynthesis are water (H2O), Carbon dioxide (CO2), and sunlight. The products of these reactants are glucose (C6H12O6) and Oxygen gas (O2). A common way to show these is: 

6CO2​ + 6H2​O + light → C6​H12​O6​ + 6O2 

Note that there are multiple copies of some of the compounds, such as the 6 carbon dioxide molecules, 6 water molecules, and 6 oxygen molecules. That happens in order to keep the balance between the two sides the same. It is impossible for a carbon molecule to appear in the products if there were no carbon molecules in the reactants. There are many other little compounds to remember in the reactions, but these are the main inputs and outputs of photosynthesis. 

Part 1: Light-Dependent Reactions 

The very first reactions of photosynthesis are called light-dependent reactions. Like the name suggests, these are the reactions that are driven by sunlight. The basis of these reactions is sunlight exciting electrons, meaning giving them power, so that they can use that energy to activate processes within the chloroplast. These reactions take place in the thylakoid membrane of the chloroplast. Thylakoids are these tower-like structures inside chloroplasts that contain chlorophyll (the green pigment that absorbs sunlight) in their membranes. 

The Electron Transport Chain 

The electron transport chain is a series of proteins that transport the electrons to their final destination. In the process, the electrons get charged up by a few of these proteins and are used to power a protein at the end of the chain, which I will get to. 

So, how are the electrons even obtained? They don’t appear out of nowhere. Well, let's give a little thanks to water for generously splitting up to provide these electrons. These water molecules split into oxygen gas, H+ ions(positive hydrogen ions), and electrons. 

Photosystem II 

A photosystem is a protein that absorbs sunlight and converts it into usable energy in the form of charged electrons. So, Photosystem II is the first photosystem in the light-dependent reaction. The name is a bit confusing, but its name comes from the fact that Photosystem II was discovered after Photosystem I. Blame the scientists, not me. 

This photosystem charges up the electrons and sends them down a series of proteins known as protein pumps.  These protein pumps are activated by the energy in the electrons. Remember those extra H+ ions from the splitting of the water molecules? The protein pumps force the ions into a space inside the thylakoid membrane (called the lumen or the thylakoid space) that is already jam-packed with H+ ions. The force of a high concentration of ions on one side and a low concentration on another side makes what's called a gradient. This comes into play later. 

Photosystem I 

This is another misleading name for a photosystem. Like I said before, Photosystem I was discovered before Photosystem II, therefore the names. After the electrons pass through the protein pumps, they are exhausted of most of their energy. Photosystem I recharges the electrons so that they can be sent to the light-independent part of photosynthesis, or the Calvin Cycle, as NADPH. Two electrons turn NADP+ and a H+ ion into NADPH, which acts as an electron carrier. 

ATP synthesis 

I already talked about the gradient that the opposite concentrations of H+ ions make. So how does the plant use it? Well, basic science tells us that high concentrations want to go toward lower concentrations. If you add something that can capture energy during this already natural process, you can get a reliable energy source. ATP Synthase acts as this in between. ATP Synthase is a protein that spins when H+ ions go through it, creating the energy needed to make ATP from ADP. Think of ADP as an uncharged battery, and ATP as a fully charged battery. ATP synthase is the charger cable that charges ADP into ATP. ATP is then sent along with the NADPH into the Calvin Cycle. 

Quick Summary of Light-Dependent Reactions 

The entirety of the light-dependent reactions is based on the charged electrons passing through the electron transport chain. If you need a quick review of light-dependent reactions (or just don’t like reading), then this should help: 

 - Takes place in the thylakoid membrane 

 - Electrons are split from water molecules 

 - Charged in Photosystem II 

 - Used to transport H+ ions into the lumen to create a gradient 

 - Electrons are charged again in Photosystem I 

 - Electrons are combined with NADP+ and H+ to make NADPH, which is sent to the Calvin Cycle 

 - ATP synthase turns ADP into ATP from the energy gradient, which is sent to the Calvin Cycle 

 Part 2: Light-Independent Reactions 

 Light-independent reactions take place in the stroma of the chloroplast, or the area in between the thylakoids that is filled with a fluid-like substance. Like the name suggests, no light is needed to activate any of the processes. This is the reaction that produces glucose, the plant’s long-awaited food. Well, almost. The outcome of the cycle is other high-energy sugars. These sugars are then, in turn, turned into glucose.

 The Calvin Cycle 

 A more common name (and honestly a better name) for the light-independent reactions is the Calvin Cycle. One of the main reasons that I say this is the fact that the reactions are a cycle, in which the excess product of the cycle’s end is used again at the beginning of the cycle. 

This is where carbon dioxide makes its debut. CO2 enters the cycle by combining with a 5-carbon molecule that was already in the cycle (this is the excess product I was talking about). If you do the math correctly, then you should get that a 6-carbon molecule is created. Usually, there are three carbon dioxide molecules that combine with three 5-carbon molecules before they enter the cycle at a time, so there would actually be three 6-carbon molecules created. These molecules are then split into six separate 3-carbon molecules. 

Now here comes the ATP and NADPH from the light-dependent reactions. The molecules split up to give their stored energy to the 3-carbon molecules. The energy enables the molecules to have a high energy yield, really meaning that they are charged batteries for the plant to use. 1 of the 3-carbon molecules is turned into a 3-carbon sugar and sent to another part of the plant to turn into glucose, the plant's energy source. The other 5 restart the cycle by turning from 5 3-carbon molecules into 3 5-carbon molecules. The cycle begins anew. 

Quick Summary of Light-Independent Reactions 

 The Calvin Cycle is the basis of the light-dependent reactions. Most of the molecules involved are made of carbon (excluding the energy molecules). Again, here is a short summary: 

 - 3 carbon dioxide (3CO2) molecules enter the cycle and combine with 3 5-carbon molecules 

 - The newly-made molecule gets split into 6 3-carbon molecules 

 - Molecules charged up by ATP and NADPH 

 - 1 3-carbon molecule exits to become glucose, others reform into 5-carbon molecules to restart the cycle 

Summary of Photosynthesis 

Photosynthesis is the way that plants make their energy. The use of electrons in the electron transport chain allows the formation of the energy carriers ATP and NADPH. These molecules, in turn, can make a 3-carbon molecule into an energy-yielding sugar. 

Photosynthesis can be a hard topic. There is a lot to remember and pack into your brain. But when you stand back and look at all of it, the pieces of the puzzle fit into place.

title: The Tug-of-War Of Procrastination
excerpt: Homework needs to be done…a bit later. Learn why people procrastinate, and hopefully learn why you have it.
author: Ishaan Sankaran
content:
When you have an assignment from Math, Science, English, and all these other classes, what is the first human instinct? Then answer the question however you want, I think that is a tad bit more engaging than starting off with 3 questions. Once we get that due date, we're able to rest, knowing we can put it away till the day before it’s due. I've even done this countless times from middle to high school. Even now, it’s still a common habit I still have. On the day before we were scrambling to finish the assignment we had been given a week ago, while also completing other assignments we had been given in school. Everything piles up, and we’re put under immense levels of stress. This can all be summed up in one word: Procrastination. And guess what? It’s not really about being lazy! 

Procrastination is a common thing among people of all ages. Many students procrastinate in school, but even beyond that, as many as 20% of adults are true procrastinators. 

Our brains start to order things by short-term benefits and long-term benefits. As a kid, did you ever remember playing a game where you could buy things with tokens? You could either buy a cheaper thing at that moment, or you could save up to get that larger prize. A lot of us have chosen the smaller thing, thinking we could get that larger prize later. That’s similar to procrastination– prioritizing short-term benefits and rewards over those that are long-term. 

Where does this habit come from? Was I born with it? Does it come from my parents’ genes? Nah. You actually learn procrastination as a habit. Procrastination becomes a way to avoid responsibility, to complete or begin tasks. Other than being a priority of benefits, procrastination can also arise from emotions that you feel after being tasked with something you don’t really want to do. 

Beyond benefit, people procrastinate because they fear failure or have self-doubt and anxiety. Mental health issues such as ADHD, not paying attention or being impulsive, depression, eating disorders, and even perfectionism. The behaviors caused by these issues could vary from eating snacks to get rid of the discomfort to not being able to start the task because you're too worried about how it may turn out. 

In the end, procrastination is a habit that changes and shapes your brain. So, let’s take a look at what exactly is happening inside your brain! 

Inside your brain, two parts called the limbic system and the prefrontal cortex clash. The limbic system is the brain’s “emotional center,” and the prefrontal cortex is the brain’s “decision-making center.” Your brain plays a game of tug-of-war as the prefrontal cortex and the limbic system fight. The limbic system opts for a change in scene and wants to flee from unpleasant tasks or work, and it pulls on the rope to make you do something more engaging, like scrolling on your phone. Your prefrontal cortex wants you to continue to do your work and follow the “planner” in your brain to complete all your tasks. So, when you’re working and the limbic system pulls the rope past the line to win, you procrastinate. 

Now that you know more about what procrastination is, why it happens, and what can cause it, how can you solve it so you can get back to doing your work and not have to pull an all-nighter before the day everything is due? 

Find a way to outsmart procrastination. Now what does that mean? That means finding a way to make your brain react differently to an unpleasant situation and break the reward-based learning loop. Mindfulness is a perfect way to do this. Mindfulness allows you to become aware of your surroundings and makes you able to curb anxiety and break negative habits– like procrastination. With mindfulness, not only does it break procrastination there are many other great benefits, such as a rise in curiosity. 

Another way you can break procrastination is by being smart about your surroundings. If you put yourself in a situation where you’re with your friends and you’re unable to focus on the work in front of you and engage in too much conversation (not pertaining to your work), that itself can be a type of procrastination. However, the small things in your surroundings matter too. Such as your phone. 

We all love to scroll or play games on our phones, and when our limbic system locks onto it and plays that game of tug-of-war with the prefrontal cortex, it usually wins out, and you’re staring at the screen while your work is undone in front of you. To overcome this, you can simply remove the distraction by leaving your phone somewhere else or setting restrictions on it. Or, going back to the reward system, you can use it positively by making a schedule and working until you reach a break. 

Now, this all may seem easier said than done, since it’s hard to do this for work you absolutely hate. If you’re in school and you have math homework, a class you absolutely hate, it's very difficult to engage yourself. 

So find a way to motivate yourself. Rather than trying to get something done, find a way to set goals for yourself and learn the content. You never know, you may even find something that is helpful or interesting. This way, you’re more focused and engaged, and you’re more likely to get work done now that you don't have to wait till the last minute. 

Procrastination is an issue we all deal with, and the more we do it, the worse and worse the habit gets. It’s not being lazy, as there are so many reasons as to why it occurs: from mental health issues to the prioritizing of rewards. Although it may be hard to pull away from the distractions, you win that game of tug-of-war against your limbic system. Know that it’s possible. You just need to put in that effort and have the right mindset. Hopefully, you’re never pulling an all-nighter, but if you are, you are not in the wrong, your Limbic System is!

title: Sustainable Marketing
excerpt: As business continues to grow and grow, so does the harm that the government incurs. In order to make a statement and save face, companies are starting to switch over to sustainable marketing, but what does it really mean for them and the environment?
author: Sridama Pulumati
content:
Once, I was shopping with my family, and we came across two different brands of water bottles, one being Nestle Pure Life, and another being some generic brand. Back then, I only focused on the cost of the bottle, so I told my dad, “Dad, let’s buy that one, it’s cheaper than this Nestle Pure Life.” My dad then told me, “Son, the one you want is cheaper, but Nestle made this bottle from recycled plastic.” It was many years later till I discovered that this is what sustainable marketing was all about. 

The first thought when asked about what sustainable marketing is is to answer that, “It’s just things that keep the environment safe, while marketing normally.” While it is true that sustainable marketing is safer for the environment, it is so much more than that. All these companies that boast their brand as being sustainable, have many reasons to do so. 

One such reason is because people started to take note of environmental conditions. Beginning in the 1960s and 1970s, many authors such as Paul Shepard, Rachel Carson and others started discussing the impacts that humans can have on the environment, and what that would mean for future generations. It also certainly helped that with Albert Einstein’s contributions to the nuclear bomb, and its use, people could see first hand the toll and damage it had on the natural environment,  decimating trees, foliage, and wildlife. 

One of the most important concepts of any business textbook, class, or lecture is the concept of building a strong brand. Branding is one of the best ways for businesses to earn money, because as soon as you’ve memorized their brand, you will always buy their products from them. By following sustainable marketing and practices, a strong, environmentally friendly brand is created in your mind, to which your hands will reciprocate by swiping your credit card or paying for a product with cash. With my dad, what convinced him to buy that Nestle bottle was the fact that they followed sustainable practices, thanks to their branding of being environmentally conscious(and their certificates and actual proof). 

This in turn soon makes a person realize that no, some businesses main goals aren’t to protect the environment, but a few simply use sustainability as an avenue to gain more customers. This in and of itself isn’t wrong, it’s just the business doing its job, but when the environmental and social impacts are exaggerated, this is called greenwashing, or false advertising. 

Lying in any society is generally frowned upon, but when a business does it, it causes irreparable damage to its reputation. When this happens, it causes them to lose many of their customers, their employees, and the trust in their product or service. For example, Volkswagen is one such company, that appears to appear more environmentally friendly, cheated emission tests by fitting the vehicles with a “defect” device, a device that detects when an emission test is occurring and alters its performance. This led to massive financial penalties, lost millions as stock holders lost faith in the company, and faced the fact that their reputation and brand was severely damaged. This, however, led to Volkswagen becoming a climate leader. Due to their green washing, the company knew it was time to change its ethics and embrace no emission vehicles. This led to the creation of its Sustainability Council, and to the decision to decarbonize, with 50 billion euros used to launch the electrification initiative. Soon, the company was rebranded and since then has focused on climate change. 

With Volkswagen’s story, it becomes clear that companies can change, and follow sustainable marketing and practices for a reason. As we have seen so far, some of these reasons are to establish a strong brand, gain customer loyalty or trust by being environmentally friendly, and to recover from the public’s loss of faith in your company. But one crucial reason other than giving back to our planet is to increase innovation. 

With customers and the public demanding more sustainable practices, such as less greenhouse gas emissions, waste, and pollution, this can lead to companies rethinking how they produce, deliver, and promote their product or service. Many people skip over the benefit of innovation when engaging in sustainable marketing. While doing sustainable marketing can gain customer trust and loyalty, and more customers, innovation is what helps the company grow beyond, and what helps the customer. When companies start innovating, they can optimize their products, improve upon their services, and just in general become a better company(setting themselves apart from their competition). One such benefit to the customer when a business innovates is that they receive their money’s worth from the company.

Sustainable marketing is no longer an optional strategy-it’s now a must for all companies in this rapidly changing economy. As more and more people learn about the environment, and how it’s being impacted by people, the businesses that are transparent, follow ethical practices, and value the customer gain customer loyalty and trust. Ultimately, sustainable marketing isn’t all about caring for the environment. It’s also about bettering yourself through innovation, gaining customer trust and loyalty, and building a strong brand.

title: The Real Life Bigfoot: Gigantopithecus Blacki
excerpt: Stories about Bigfoot have fascinated people for decades. Descriptions of a towering, ape-like creature roaming dense forests appear in cultures around the world, from North America’s Bigfoot to the Himalayan Yeti.
author: Aniketh Narra
content:
Stories about Bigfoot have fascinated people for decades. Descriptions of a towering, ape-like creature roaming dense forests appear in cultures around the world, from North America’s Bigfoot to the Himalayan Yeti. While these creatures remain legends, the idea of a giant ape is not entirely fictional. In fact, a real primate once existed that was massive enough to make these myths seem believable. That ape was Gigantopithecus blacki (pronounced jigh-gan-toh-pi-THEE-kuss BLAK-ee), an enormous primate that lived alongside early humans in Asia. Similar in appearance to a modern orangutan but far larger, Gigantopithecus blacki is believed to be the largest ape to have ever lived. Standing significantly taller and weighing far more than any ape alive today, its size alone set it apart from all other primates. By examining the fossils it left behind, scientists have been able to uncover where it lived, how it survived, and why such a powerful creature ultimately went extinct. 

Where and When was it found? 

Fossils of Gigantopithecus blacki have been found in southern China, Vietnam, Thailand, and Indonesia. The very first discovery happened in 1935, when a scientist noticed an unusually large tooth being sold in a Hong Kong market. From discoveries like this, scientists believe this giant ape lived in dense forests across China from about 2.3 million to 215,000 years ago, with its population beginning to decline around 300,000 years ago. However, since most of what we’ve found are teeth and jaw fragments, one big mystery remains: what did this massive creature actually look like? 

What did Gigantopithecus blacki look like? 

Because complete fossils haven’t been found, scientists rely on teeth and jaw fragments to estimate what Gigantopithecus blacki looked like. These remains make it difficult to know its exact proportions, but the evidence points to a giant ape unlike anything alive today. Researchers estimate it stood about 9 to 10 feet tall and weighed anywhere from 440 to more than 1,200 pounds. That makes Gigantopithecus blacki the largest ape ever discovered, far bigger than the Eastern Lowland gorilla, the largest ape living today. This extreme size shaped nearly every part of its life, including how it ate and survived in its environment. 

What did it Potentially Eat? 

Gigantopithecus blacki’s massive body and specialized digestive system allowed it to process large amounts of tough, fibrous vegetation. This advantage helped the ape survive on abundant but low-quality foods such as bamboo. Researchers think its diet included bamboo shoots, stems, fruits, and tubers. Evidence from fossilized teeth and jaws shows clear adaptations for grinding and crushing plant material, which supports its classification as a herbivore. Overall, its physical structure and dental features point to a plant-based diet suited for dense forests. Understanding its diet helps clarify how Gigantopithecus survived in its environment. Understanding what it ate helps explain how it thrived, but diet alone did not determine its fate. To fully understand its survival, scientists must also consider the dangers Gigantopithecus faced. 

What were its Predators? 

Because of its massive size, adult Gigantopithecus blacki likely had very few predators. However, their young were much more vulnerable. Predators such as tigers, leopards, and crocodiles near rivers may have hunted juveniles when they were small and defenseless. Even so, fully grown adults were so large that most predators would have avoided them altogether. Their size alone likely acted as a deterrent, and parents could defend their offspring if danger appeared. But if predators weren’t a major threat, one big question remains: why did Gigantopithecus blacki still go extinct? 

What Caused their Extinction? 

For a long time, scientists suspected that Gigantopithecus blacki went extinct because its forest home slowly disappeared. Newer research supports this idea. Around 700,000 years ago, dense forests filled with pine, birch, and chestnut-like trees began to shrink. In their place, open habitats with large grasslands spread across Southeast Asia. This shift made survival much harder for Gigantopithecus. It depended on forest plants for food, and as those plants became scarce, finding enough to eat grew difficult. At the same time, tectonic changes in the region altered the climate, further changing habitats and food availability. While the environment was changing rapidly, Gigantopithecus blacki could not adapt quickly enough. Its massive size, once an advantage, became a disadvantage in a world that favored flexibility. Scientists are still studying whether this extinction happened the same way everywhere or if different populations faced different challenges. But one thing is clear: it wasn’t just change that caused the extinction, it was the inability to keep up with it. 

This pattern becomes clearer when Gigantopithecus blacki is compared to Pongo weidenreichi, a close relative of modern orangutans that lived in the same region. Unlike Gigantopithecus, Pongo weidenreichi showed greater adaptability as forests shrank and environments became more mixed. It was able to adjust its diet and behavior to survive in fragmented forests and changing climates. Gigantopithecus, however, remained heavily dependent on dense forest vegetation and lacked the flexibility needed to cope with expanding grasslands. While both apes faced the same environmental pressures, only Pongo weidenreichi adapted successfully, reinforcing the idea that Gigantopithecus went extinct not simply because its environment changed, but because it could not adapt fast enough. 

Gigantopithecus blacki remains one of the most mysterious primates ever discovered. Even today, scientists are working to answer key questions about how this giant ape lived and why it failed to survive environmental change. Current research focuses on dental wear patterns, enamel thickness, and isotopic analysis of teeth to better understand its exact diet and how specialized it truly was. Researchers are also refining fossil dates to map population decline across regions and studying whether the ape could move efficiently through forests or adapt its feeding strategies. One major unknown is how flexible its behavior really was, including whether it could climb well, travel long distances for food, or adjust to shrinking forest patches. What is clear is that extreme size and specialization, once advantages, became disadvantages in a rapidly changing world. Gigantopithecus blacki did not disappear because it was weak, but because it could not adapt fast enough. Just as stories of Bigfoot capture our imagination today, the real-life giant ape shows us that the line between myth and reality can be surprisingly thin, and that even the mightiest creatures must adapt or vanish.

title: AI in Genetic Testing
excerpt: Artificial Intelligence has the potential to revolutionize genetic testing, though this brand-new arena of genetics and technology comes with both impressive accuracy improvements, and rising ethical concerns.
author: Kavin Puri
content:
Artificial intelligence allows us to live in a world where computer programs can perform complex calculations far faster than humans could even begin to solve them, where our smartphones are more powerful than the supercomputers used to control the rockets that placed Neil Armstrong on the moon. Yet, although neural networks have existed since 1951, we’ve only recently begun to utilize their full potential in healthcare for tasks such as diagnosing conditions and identifying the most effective treatments. This shift has largely come from reducing costs and improving accuracy, as over ¼ of global healthcare spending is wasted annually. AI can rapidly analyze a patient's situation and make accurate predictions about crucial health information through its ability to analyze the data of millions of data points from vast datasets. 

One of Artificial Intelligence’s latest applications in healthcare is helping to interpret DNA sequences during genetic testing, which enables the analysis of a patient’s history, assessment of potential disease risks, and guidance of treatment decisions by sifting through the 3 billion base pairs of our nuclear code. However, despite being able to increase the accuracy and efficiency of treatment, the use of AI in genetic testing raises important ethical and reliability concerns. If I were to take a genetic test one day, I would prefer AI to aid in analyzing and interpreting my genetic test results.  I would also want feedback from experienced geneticists and other medical professionals to ensure the reliability of my findings. 

AI is often used in genetic testing due to its ability to process vast amounts of genetic data rapidly and efficiently. We have come a long way with the time it takes to sequence the average human genome, reducing it from over 13 years back in 1990 to just a few hours today, a phenomenal feat that could not have been possible without complex algorithms analyzing massive amounts of data. In just 10 years, AI has helped us reduce the cost of analyzing a whole genome (all of the DNA of an organism such as us humans) from $20,000 to under $1,500 , greatly increasing the availability of genetic testing to the public. Most importantly, AI has rapidly increased in accuracy; a recently developed AI algorithm from Harvard achieved a 94% accuracy in detecting various cancer types, surpassing existing AI methods by up to 36%. This level of precision can significantly improve early diagnosis and preventive care, potentially saving someone’s life. 

AI can also identify genetic risk factors for genetically related diseases such as cancer and Alzheimer’s, enhancing predictive accuracy and tailoring treatment recommendations to individual patients. One current method of testing for diseases is through Polygenic Risk Scores, or PRS, which calculates the chances of an individual developing diseases based on multiple genetic variants in their DNA. AI enhances PRS accuracy by combining large-scale studies containing thousands of patient data points with Machine Learning models, allowing better risk accuracy for these diseases. 

In addition to analyzing DNA sequences, AI programs have adapted to display a more complete picture of human health through methods that widen the scope beyond our cells’ DNA. For example, metagenomics involves sequencing the DNA of the microbes and bacteria that live in our gut in human samples linked to certain diseases. AI algorithms can analyze terabytes of microbial data to identify disease-related microbial signatures and diagnose conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease and colorectal cancer. Another technique is epigenetic - the study of how genes can be chemically turned on/off - analysis. In particular, AI-powered methylation analysis has been used to detect early-stage cancers by identifying epigenetic changes in blood samples specific to them. 

Despite these advantages, relying solely on AI for genetic interpretation has certain risks. First, AI models are only as effective as the datasets used to train them, and a lack of diverse data can lead to inaccurate conclusions & biased results. Furthermore, as AI becomes more prevalent in healthcare, misinterpretation or an overreliance on its findings may lead to poor medical decisions. Using large patient datasets to train machine-learning models may also be a privacy concern, so it is necessary to enforce strict security protocols. Most importantly, AI cannot consider ethical and emotional factors when delivering sensitive health information, replacing a trusted physician’s empathy with machine-generated results.  However, when we consider both the benefits and risks of using AI in genetic testing, it is clear that when used carefully, AI holds tremendous potential to significantly advance genetic research and improve treatment outcomes, ultimately helping the health of millions in the years to come.

title: A Journey Into Deep Learning
excerpt: This article ventures into the heart of deep learning, tracing how machines learn to see, think, and understand in ways that challenge what it means to be intelligent.
author: Arnav Deokule
content:
Like many people growing up in the glowing age of screens and gadgets, I spent countless hours trying to find out how machines “knew” things. How did my phone recognize my face? How did a small speaker in my room suddenly recognize my voice and answer questions like a modern day genie? Back then, I used to think that computers were magical items, until I discovered the true secret behind their intelligence. Turns out - they weren’t powered by magic. Their power came from something far more fascinating: the learning minds of machines. These quiet digital revolutionaries, made of nothing but math and code, changed the world. They were the artificial neurons that sparked a new era. This is the world of deep learning. 

Deep learning, at its core, is a subfield of artificial intelligence The foundation of deep learning lies in artificial neural networks, structures designed loosely after the neurons in the human brain. A neural network is made of layers: an input layer that receives information, an output layer that makes a prediction, and many hidden layers in between. Each layer is made of artificial “neurons” that perform mathematical operations, passing information forward while adjusting internal parameters known as weights. These adjustments allow the network to gradually improve its accuracy. 

To understand how deep learning truly works, imagine giving a network thousands of images of cats. The network does not begin by understanding what a cat is. Instead, early layers identify simple patterns like curves, edges, or colors. Mid-level layers combine these patterns into shapes such as ears or whiskers. Deeper layers form full concepts—paws, tails, faces. After seeing enough examples, the network learns to generalize, recognizing a new cat it has never encountered. This ability to automatically learn hierarchical patterns from raw data is what sets deep learning apart from earlier forms of AI. 

Deep learning also thrives on large datasets. The more varied and abundant the examples, the better the network becomes. Advances in computing power, especially the use of GPUs and specialized processors, have allowed networks with millions—and now billions—of parameters to train on massive collections of images, text, audio, and video. This surge in data and speed is what enabled deep learning to move from research labs into everyday life. 

The results are everywhere. Deep learning powers facial recognition systems on smartphones. It allows virtual assistants to understand natural speech. It drives recommendation engines on platforms like YouTube and Spotify. In medicine, deep learning models detect tumors and diseases earlier and more accurately than many traditional methods. In transportation, self-driving cars rely heavily on neural networks to interpret roads, signs, obstacles, and movement. Even creative tasks—writing, drawing, music composition—have been transformed by deep learning models capable of generating new content from learned patterns. 

Despite its successes, deep learning has important limitations. Neural networks are often described as “black boxes” because their internal decision-making processes are difficult to interpret. Understanding exactly why a model made a certain prediction remains a major challenge in AI research. Deep learning also depends heavily on the data it is trained on. If the data contains biases, the model may unintentionally learn and reproduce those biases. This makes responsible data selection and ethical training practices essential. 

Researchers continue to push the boundaries of deep learning. Some study how to make networks more explainable, so humans can understand their reasoning. Others focus on making models more efficient, allowing them to learn from fewer examples. There is ongoing work to combine deep learning with symbolic reasoning, giving AI systems the ability to understand logic, cause-and-effect, and abstract thinking. These advancements aim to overcome the current limitations of deep learning and lead toward more general and reliable forms of artificial intelligence. 

As deep learning evolves, it not only teaches machines but also teaches us about learning itself. It forces scientists, engineers, and philosophers to rethink what intelligence means—how it forms, how it grows, and how it can emerge in systems very different from the human brain. The study of deep learning has become a study of both technology and cognition, blurring the line between artificial and natural intelligence. 

Deep learning has transformed the world in less than a decade. It writes stories, paints pictures, drives cars, diagnoses illnesses, translates languages, predicts trends, analyzes patterns, and learns constantly. Yet it remains a mystery wrapped in code—an evolving universe of algorithms that both mimic and challenge human intelligence. Deep learning pushes us to understand not just machines, but ourselves. 

We may never fully comprehend how far this journey will take us. But, much like staring at the night sky and wondering about black holes, we can explore. We can learn. 

We can imagine. 

And that might be the greatest power deep learning has given us—the ability to see the future not as a distant possibility, but as something already unfolding before our eyes.

title: The Cheesy Lie We’ve All Believed
excerpt: Do mice really like cheese or is it just one big cheesy mice-conception?
author: Anusha Gupta
content:
Have you ever watched the cartoon Tom and Jerry as a kid? If you haven't, trust me, you are missing out. Until you get a chance to watch it, here’s a recap. Tom is a cat who is always chasing after Jerry the mouse, who is always on the hunt for cheese. 

But wait? Cheese? 

Tom and Jerry has made cheese the golden treasure at the end of a rainbow, the ultimate prize in the mice world. But did you know that mice don’t really like cheese? 

WHAT?! 

Yes, I’m as shocked as you are. Sure, mice will munch on cheese if there's nothing else around but it is definitely not their favorite food. If you have a huge sweet tooth like me, you better watch out since mice are generally more attracted to sugary foods such as cookies, cake, fruits, as well as grains! Fun fact: if mice can’t find anything to eat, they will actually eat their own droppings. They do this so they can get the nutrients they need out of their bacteria. 

DISGUSTING I KNOW!  But hey, you gotta do what you gotta do. I respect the hustle. 

The real question is…Why did this myth even come to be? 

This myth comes from a time where refrigeration wasn’t a thing yet. Since refrigeration did not exist it was hard for families to preserve food. Some ways to preserve food back in the day included hanging meat from the ceiling, storing grains in bags and covering large barrels of cheese with a cheese cloth. Out of all of these options, mice found the cheese the easiest thing to access compared to the meat and grains making it the more appealing food for them to snack on. 

Another reason why mice gravitate away from cheese is because of its smell. I think we all know how pungent some cheese can be. The cheese Limburger is known for being a cheese with the smell of feet and Vieux Boulogne is known for being the world's stinkiest cheese from a 2004 and 2007 study. YUCK, I can smell this stinky cheese through the screen. But the reason mice gravitate away from cheese is because they have a very sensitive sense of smell. This is due to the fact that 1% of their DNA is dedicated to olfactory receptors which are sensory neurons in their nose that detect odor molecules, and they have around 10 million olfactory receptors! We can only imagine how sensitive their noses are with this many receptors. Did you know that mice also have a second nose located in their nasal cavity called a vomeronasal organ and it is used to smell pheromones which are chemical signals released by animals to communicate. Instead of search dogs we need search mice because with two noses, they could do double the work! 

Let’s talk about how this misconception actually spread. The root of this misconception would be television and shows from the middle ages. In the play, King Lear, written by Shakesphere, there is the phrase spoken by the character Lear where he uses a piece of toasted cheese to try to catch a mouse showing that the connection between mice and cheese dates back much further back than we thought. This misconception only started there,  but then spread through the use of television which can be seen through the show Tom and Jerry. Animators used cheese as the main food because it was the easiest food item to draw. Way to take the easy way out animators! Just kidding but let’s think about it logically, no one wants to draw 10 pieces of grain every single time, a yellow triangle just seems much more logical and less time consuming. Since it was the most effective way, animators did not draw or animate anything else, spreading the misconception that mice and cheese go hand and hand. 

Going back to my Tom and Jerry obsession, someone needs to tell the animator that Tom is gonna eventually catch Jerry because sooner or later Jerry’s going to ditch the cheese and go for some cake. Now we also know what to actually put in our mouse traps, hint: it's not cheese! 

It is actually crazy how we’ve all grown up believing that mice are obsessed with cheese. But in reality, it’s just one big, cheesy mice-conception.

title: Does Hair Actually Grow Faster When You Cut It?
excerpt: Does hair actually grow faster after you cut it? This article challenges and debunks this myth with the science of hair growth.
author: Sreenidh Durisheti
content:
On March 11th 2022, TikToker the.osh.01 uploaded a video titled, “Shaving my face every single morning until I grow a full-on beard”. It seemed contradictory– wouldn’t shaving reset facial hair progress? The creator believed that hair grew faster with each shave. With this logic, each cut would make the hair grow faster and faster, eventually leading to a full beard. Nevertheless, the answer is yes: it does reset progress. The.osh.01 has since stopped uploading videos. But his last video, Day 716, shows him with no beard in sight. While the challenge itself was meant for comedic purposes, it challenges a widespread myth: Does hair grow faster after you cut it? 

This myth is commonly pushed by parents, friends, and influencers. As a result, a large number of people believe this myth to be true. When you hear something from people you trust or watch online, it’s easy to accept it as fact. Like many popular myths, repetition makes it feel true. 

I once believed in this myth as well, using it as a coping mechanism for the treachery my barber displayed when cutting my hair. The reality is that cutting your hair has little to no correlation with faster hair growth. 

It is believed that this myth originated from the fact that hair appears healthier after a trim. However, the problem with this assumption is that hair growth does not come from the ends of hair. Rather, it depends on your follicle and scalp health. 

Many people imagine hair growth as a plant. They think trimming the ends is like cutting off old leaves to help the plant grow better. The key difference is that hair isn’t alive like plants are. The cells that are cut are dead cells. Cutting your hair can make it look healthier and smoother, but that is not correlated to hair growth speed. 

Going back to TikToker the.osh.01., he may have taken on this challenge due to believing in this myth, particularly with shaving. When you shave or trim hair, the new end is blunt and flat. Blunt ends make hair look thicker or darker, which tricks your brain into thinking your hair grew more quickly than before. But it’s just an illusion. The real growth comes from your hair follicles. 

Hair follicles are the structures within your skin that actually grow your hair. Follicles are tube-like structures that surround the root and strand of a hair. Hair follicles exist in the top two layers of your skin. You’re born with over 5 million hair follicles in your body and over one million hair follicles on your head. As you age, hair grows out of your hair follicles. 

It is mistakenly believed that hair growth comes from the ends of hair. However, since hair growth comes from hair follicles, cutting hair has no correlation to the speed of hair growth. In fact, the average growth of hair per month is 0.5 cm to 1.7 cm or 0.2 to 0.7 inches. 

There is no scientifically proven method for increasing the speed of hair growth. Hair growth occurs by cells forming in the hair bulb under the follicle. Additionally, there is also no method that increases the speed at which these cells form. This includes well known methods such as oil, stress management, supplements and nutrition. 

At the end of the day, the myth that cutting hair makes it grow faster survives because it feels true, not because it is true. Hair may look thicker or healthier after a trim, but that doesn’t change the speed of the follicles working under your skin. Although it's sad, even if the.osh.01 continued the challenge for decades, he would never have a full beard. Ultimately, science debunks this challenge and highlights the importance of researching things before believing them.

title: The Miracle Behind Half a Brain
excerpt: What happens when a child loses half their brain—yet somehow gains their life back? This article explores the extraordinary science of neuroplasticity and the children who redefine what the human brain can do.
author: Vedika Kamble
content:
Imagine this – you’re waiting outside the doctor's office for your diagnosis. Each second stretching longer than the last. Suddenly, your name gets called. You then scramble to gather all your things and head into the office. You anxiously settle down on the chair, as an eerie silence follows. 

The doctor studies your report for a long moment before slowly turning to you,” Our last resort to stop the seizures is surgery.” He looks up to you and says, “It would mean we have to remove the left part of your brain.” 

Your heart sinks. You start to reconsider if you heard the right words. Before the shock can even sink in, a thousand questions flash through your mind. 

How is that even possible? Am I going to survive this? Will my brain still function? 

What we don’t realize is that this is a common scenario, faced by many children diagnosed with uncontrollable seizures confined to a single hemisphere of the brain. 

Wait... what does that even mean? And why are such extreme surgeries even done? 

To understand this, we need to zoom into the basic building block of our nervous system: the neuron, a cell that transports electrical and chemical signals throughout the body. Neurons transport stimuli at an unbelievable speed, enabling various communication pathways to link the brain and every corner of our body. Their highly branched structure allows them to form connections with multiple neurons, ultimately making an intricate spider web- like network of billions. 

Epilepsy is a chronic brain disorder where certain groups of neurons become overreactive and send out abnormal signals, triggering seizures. In most cases, the electrical storm begins at a specific spot in the brain - the ‘focus.’  From here, the signals spread like ripples, but when the seizures stay trapped in only one half of the brain, it’s known as focal epilepsy, typically only affecting one side of the body. 

Sometimes during the seizures, you are fully aware of everything. Other times, the seizure sweeps in, stealing your consciousness before you know it. 

If such seizures continue at a regular basis, they are proven to cause injury or even death. 

In the most severe, relentless epilepsy cases where even medical treatment fails, doctors turn to a drastic, but lifesaving procedure, called Hemispherectomy. (hemi – half, sphere- here referring to a hemisphere of brain, ectomy- here referring to surgical removal). 

A surgery that involves careful removal of the affected half of the brain. Great caution needs to be taken while cutting the sensitive tissue, as one mistake could lead to the destruction of vital neural pathways! 

Hemispherectomy is considered to be one of the most invasive, yet most successful epilepsy surgery in the world of neurosurgery. 

Wait, but what happens to empty space left behind? 

Well, the surgeons developing the procedure struggled to find an answer. They tried to find various substitutes, and believe it or not, they even tried to fill the empty space with sterile ping pong balls! 

Until they finally concluded that the empty cavity was filled by the brain’s Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF). 

Surprisingly, even after having half of their brain removed, most children still go on to live a full, and remarkable life, even developing personalities! 

Not only that, but most of these kids are cured of their seizures, and have the potential to grow their cognitive, linguistic, and reasoning skills. Researchers also discovered an increased number of brain networks in these patients compared to an average, healthy human brain. 

Woah, it’s almost like the brain whipped out its own wand and started making magical new neural networks. 

But how does that even work? 

If you cut your phone in half, it’s obviously not going to turn on. So how does the brain still continue to function? 

Think of it as a superpower the brain possesses called ‘Neuroplasticity’. The sudden loss of tissue pushes the brain to get into action. It rewires and reorganizes its connections, slowly adopting the role of the removed part. Younger children often show the most dramatic recovery. Their brains are still in a dynamic, growth-heavy stage, making rewiring faster and more effective. Neuroplasticity serves as an essential tool to compensate for the loss of function. 

But the body obviously isn’t going to completely return to a perfect normal state. After the surgery, children face partial vision loss, difficulty in forming thoughts, and weakness in one side of their body. With the help of neuroplasticity their cognitive and physical functions can be developed. Speech and physical therapy can help to strengthen the newly built and developing neural pathways. 

The brain’s ability to adapt and transform is nothing short of a miracle. 

The human brain is full of mysteries and hidden superpowers that we’re just beginning to uncover… but the real question is, how much more is it really capable of?
